title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SEATTLE (AP) — The Seattle SuperSonics didn't just defeat the Charlotte Hornets on Tuesday night; they provided the national stage for one of the most singularly dominant defensive performances the game has ever seen. While the final score read 102-81 in favor of the Sonics, the entire narrative was authored by Gary Payton.

Payton, the Defensive Player of the Year, transcended his own lofty standards, turning a regular-season contest into a personal clinic. His final line was staggering: 20 points, 11 assists, 9 rebounds, and an astounding **11 steals**. He was a thief in the night, perpetually lurking in passing lanes and stripping Charlotte ball-handlers with impunity. His relentless pressure shattered the Hornets’ offensive rhythm, creating a cascade of fast-break opportunities that fueled the Sonics’ attack.

While Detlef Schrempf provided efficient scoring support with 21 points, and Vin Baker controlled the paint with a 19-point, 11-rebound double-double, they were secondary actors in the Payton showcase. The Hornets, led by Glen Rice’s 19 points, simply had no answer for the onslaught. Every dribble was contested, every pass a risk. Payton’s energy was infectious, galvanizing a defensive effort that held Charlotte to a paltry 81 points.

The game was a testament to a generational talent at the peak of his powers. To register a triple-double is a rare feat; to achieve one anchored by a double-digit steal total borders on mythology. Payton wasn't just playing the game; he was rewriting the definition of defensive artistry, leaving a stunned opponent and an electrified home crowd as witnesses to a night they would not soon forget.
